stem: A 17-year-old female presents to the labor and delivery unit for induction of labor. Based on the documentation in the Marital Status & Legal Authorization tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Minor client requesting epidural anesthesia and surgical consent if needed.
Background: 17 years old, 40 weeks gestation. Parents are currently out of state.
Assessment: Client states, 'I've been married for 6 months, here is my certificate. I can sign for myself, right?'
Recommendation: Verify state-specific emancipation rules for married minors.

actionOptions.text: Witness the client's own signature on the surgical and anesthesia consent forms
Verify the certified copy of the marriage certificate in the medical record
Delay all procedures until a biological parent provides telephone consent

parameterOptions.text: Client's understanding of the risks/benefits of the epidural

Distance of the biological parents from the facility

rationale.correct: In most jurisdictions, a minor who is legally married is automatically considered emancipated (c1) for the purpose of medical decision-making. The nurse should verify the marriage documentation (a2) and then proceed to witness the client's own signature on the consent forms (a1). The nurse must still ensure the client understands the risks (p1) and that the medical record is legally complete (p2).
clinicalPearls: Marriage, Military Service, and Court orders are the three most common paths to emancipation.
The minor's spouse does NOT sign for them; the minor signs for themselves.
Once emancipated, parents have NO legal right to the minor's medical information without a signed release.

questionTrap.trap: Requiring a parent even when the minor is married.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NCLEX treats married minors as independent adults. Treat them as if they were 21!

mnemonic.title: Emancipation E's
mnemonic.expansion: E-Established Marriage. E-Enlisted in Military. E-Exited by court (Decree).
